title: Can I still get a good job if I have bad grades in high school? - Quora

response.answer_text: It really depends what you mean by “good job”. Will you ge able to find work….yes. Will you be able to earn enough to live on…..yes. Will you get raises and progress in the company that employs you….maybe. Will you reach a salary ceiling at a relatively low level….probably. Will you advance in the company and work you way up into a better and higher paying job….probably not, or if you do, it will take many, many years. The skills learned in HS are so fundamental that they apply to virtually every job, everywhere. Simple math, simply grammar, vocabulary, syntax, a basic understanding of science and society. These are not just academic subjects, they are the basis of survival in a modern society - much as hunting and tracking skills were essential to our caveman origins. There will always be a need for manual labor and unskilled workers and you will always be able to get a job as a dishwasher or a gardener or a ditch digger but you will also forever be stuck in the economic category of the poor or the lower middle class with a peak lifetime cap on your annual salary of perhaps $30,000 or $40,000 after many years of experience. That’s about $25/hr in wages. For a long time you will work at minimum wage and it will grow very slowly over the years. If that is what you want and you are satisfied with it, then you got no worries. If you want more out of life, you’ll have to find the motivation and the effort needed to learn the basics - and get your GED. If you want a life of comfort and plenty, you’ll need to find the spark and internal mental inspiration that will drive you to learn the basics and then go on to learn the more technical or detailed skills (from a college or technical school) that will give you a shot at the better jobs at higher pay. There is one alternative that I can offer and even recommend. Go into the military. They will educate you, give you a good job and if you are not a total screw up, you will advance in rank and pay. It also offers one of the best retirement plans that there is after a shorter working career than most other jobs. Someone that joins at 18 or 19 can actually retire with a livable income at an age of under 40. You then get out with 20+ yrs of experience, a lifetime income and are young enough to start a whole new career doing something similar or completely different. I got drafted during Viet Nam and it totally sucked for the first 2 years but then I began to advance in rank and stopped doing the sh*t jobs and it got a lot better. They even sent my back to college, paid for everything and made me an officer. I retired at 45 yrs old as a full Commander (O-5) and three college degrees, and now have a nice pension + free medical for life. I started a second career as a consultant and did another 20 yrs at that - ending up with a very comfortable retirement in which I have everything I want - 3 cars, 3 houses and a farm, a boat, an RV and an airplane (ultralight) and I sent (and paid for) my kids to go to college. It’s worth considering. Good luck.

I don’t know why you’re worried about failing high school, but if it’s due to your temperament or circumstances, maybe you should look into alternative routes. (If it’s because you’re lazy and/or stupid, I can’t help you.) Maybe you should first ask yourself whether a high school education, or a university education, will really help you get a good job in the future. The basic premise is that school prepares you for the future. You learn the basic skills you will need, and also how to play the game - you show up on time, do as you are told, get along with the people around you, complete the work assigned and produce the “output” required. Eventually they give you a certificate saying that you’re fit to be hired and you spend the next forty years playing the game, except that this time you have to do useful work and the output required is some product or service that pleases your customers. They give your organisation some money because they’re happy with what you created, and this enables the organisation to continue existing and pay you a salary. Interestingly, fifty years ago the Fortune 500 list of companies was more or less static. It didn’t change much. These days, companies disappear all the time. They either fail or get taken over, and in both cases this means people get fired. The rate of change on the Fortune 500 is accelerating too. Within organisations, automation is bringing into question the whole concept of useful work. For example, this article makes a pretty convincing case for the end of a lot of the so-called “knowledge jobs” that school is supposed to equip you for. Manufacturing is already no place to spend your future, driving jobs are on the way out. Everything from doctoring to lawyering and teaching is also facing enormous changes in the coming decade or two. Assuming that you manage to find some useful work to do that isn’t being automated, you already know about outsourcing, right? Instead of keeping someone on salary, even during the non-busy times, you just pay them when they work. There is no security or stability, whatever kind of work you do. To get these jobs - or “gigs” - you need to compete with pretty much everyone in the world. I am a teacher, and I am in competition with low-cost labour from eg the Philippines, as well as retired professionals in top US cities. They have paid off their mortgages, but now they find their pensions have been slashed due to the financial crisis a few years ago and they need some extra income. They’re highly qualified, but working for peanuts because that’s what the market will pay. And it’s worth noting that a great deal of time and bandwidth is being devoted to the question of “how do I manage young people” by the people who run businesses today. There is a common perception that the next generation is basically useless, can’t contribute, etc. I’m not saying that this is a fair assessment, just that there is obviously some gap in understanding between the generation doing he hiring and the generation wanting to be hired. To prepare you for this world, someone with a relatively secure income and limited understanding of life in the real world has to create a syllabus. And they have to envision the skills and knowledge you will need ten years in the future. Think about that. Ten years ago, the world was on the brink of an unprecedented financial crisis that nobody knew was coming. Nobody was seriously considering the possibility that the next president of the USA would be a black man. The mobile phone industry was dominated by a company called Nokia, and experts were united in laughing at rumours that Apple was going to enter the market. Facebook was a startup, just for students at certain colleges, and 3d printing was unheard of. Russia’s military was no threat to anyone, and Al-Qaeda was on the ropes. How much do you think your teachers know about the future? What can they predict? What can they teach you that will be of use ten years from now? Nobody uses a pen any more. Who will type when speech-to-text can do the job perfectly? Why exactly will you need mathematics? Does anyone use that stuff today? I’m an old-school true believer in the intrinsic value of basic skills like reading, writing, critical thinking and numeracy. But even if they are useful in the future, is school the only place to obtain them? Can you do better for yourself elsewhere? Most jobs, most work, are not advertised. Positions are filled as the result of recommendations. It’s not what you know, it’s who you know. If you have a portfolio of work done, satisfied customers telling their friends about you, then you will get more work. Nobody actually cares about your certificates, if you can get the job done. The certifications exist as a proxy, they state that you’re competent if you don’t have any history to prove it. Once you have the history, the paperwork fades into the background. Obviously you need to pick a direction, and then you need to start accumulating not only the skills and knowledge you need, but also the connections. THE MOST important skill is networking. You need to make friends with people who can help you, and start building a reputation. You can start just by doing work on taskrabbit, upwork, italki, or any other online platform that suits you and keeps a record of your work and customer feedback. If you’re interested in software, get on github and start building. Learn to do the work, build your reputation, and all you have to do then is compete with everyone else in the world. A certificate might give you a small advantage, but it might also be a distraction from the real business of your life. Hope this helps. Unfortunately, nobody really has the answer to this. You might try looking up Seth Godin’s blog and signing up to his newsletter. He has a lot to say about school!

If you learn a trade or profession, and excell at it, your school grades will mean nothing. I got average grades, but had some good-paying jobs. In 1970, I was making over $14/hr starting pay. In 1976, I worked about 6 or less hour days, at $100/day, which wasn't bad. I've made up to $150/hr working on high-current power supplies, because I am good at it, but am now retired. I've seen instances I could have made over $1000/hr, while undercutting someone else's price, but that repair wasn't needed. It was a few cheap parts, instead, and I wouldn't cheat my customer. He wouldn't have known, if I had, but he appreciated me saving him almost $36,000, plus a week or more down-time, plus lost production. All this is with a high school diploma. I had a semester of college, just to take a course I wanted. I should have just bought the book, and skipped the course. Whatever you do, be the best, at least in your local area.

It's possible, but it's highly unlikely. Of the many things we learn in high school, one of them is to persist in tacking difficult and boring tasks and subjects, and dealing with them successfully. It's one of the qualities that employers look for in employees, because most work is routine, not exciting, and needs persistence because it's important to the company. If you're still in high school, it's not too late to turn things around.  If you've graduated, head for a communuty college and make a record for yourself, so you can either land a job from there, or go on to a four year college and get a degree, setting you on the course for a career.

Got to a community college, study hard, and get good grades. In general, it you complete your associate’s degree or at a minimum 30 hours of courses and then apply to transfer to a four year college, the four year school won’t even look at your high school record. It’s the one attaboy that essentially erases all the cumulative crappy grades from high school. Or at a community college you can complete an associate of applied science degree, which focuses on preparing you for a profession. My son is taking Manufacturing Technology, and since he completed his CNC (computer numerical control) course, he has had a pile of job offers because CNC programmer/operators are scarce in the marketplace. Average pay for this job in our area is $20/hour.

Only you can answer that. I've known many people who didn't do well in school but became happy and successful adults. There are many reasons students don't flourish in school, but it doesn't have to define you. I taught quite a few students who I knew to be very bright, but unmotivated. It frustrated me because I saw such potential. One of those students lost his life at 20 in a drunk driving accident. If you are sabotaging your own future, it might be time to regroup and think about what's important to you. Friends and feuds from school will be distant memories, but building a good work ethic and appreciated for learning lasts forever.

There are probably a few, but I haven't heard of a single job that would look at high school grades if you went on to college. This is a difficult question to answer because it depends on the field, and it depends on your experience in that field. If you are in tech and have bad grades in school but have worked on many different projects (open source software, a website with lots of traffic, some kind of really useful tool, etc...), and also have a few connections, grades will make very little difference. If you don't have good grades and you don't have any experience to show for, start hustling.

What would you like - a good job or a well paid job? Think. Yes, you can get a good job (with high school fail), but to climb to the top for a well paid job may take you a life time and when you reach the top, they may still over look you for a high school or college graduate. Down the roller coaster again… Would you not prefer take the elevator or escalator (of education) for well paid job and make it a good job! Think about it.

Pretty much, yes. The grades are simply a reflection of how well you have learned to learn. If you finish high school with bad grades, then you haven’t learned out to learn. If you haven’t learned how to learn, you’re going to be doomed in this fast-paced, rapid fire, changes-happening-every-day culture we live in.

Yes. What kind of job are you interested in? What subjects were you bad in? There is a reason for everything. I although I graduated from high school, the diploma is regarded as a passport to apply for any joy you want. Some jobs want an A student and some don’t give a hoot but will train you in the job they want help in. You know what I mean? So, in today’s world you could be a school dropout and still have a good job. And furthermore, what do you consider to be a “good job”? Hmm.

The important question is why did you have bad grades. Did you not put in the effort, did you not put in the work  or did you try your best and just was unable to do the work. No one will really care about your grades in high school or what they do care about is your work ethic and your ability to learn and to get along with others.

Absolutely… Learn how to interact with people well and learn how to solve problems in the workplace while still interacting well with people. Beyond that, begin to look at the world around you as not doing things to get a grade but rather as a means of serving others.

There is no reason why you should have a bad future. There was a guy that cane in to talk at my school, he got something like 5 Ds at gcse and didnt do A levels. He now runs his own business and earns a good salary. Moral of the story: not everyone is good in school but if you commit hard enough in later life anything is possible.

Yeah  of course, I have met several people who have performed terribly during their school years. Despite being labelled "unpotential", they still manage to be successful later in life, even several hold important positions as CEOs
Ofcourse you are，you have a long way need to walk，The high school is just a small step.you need discover the problem and mend it. you will be successful if you always know what mistakes you had make.

It possible but it decides on what you want to do,everyone do not employ people with bad grades but they are some good jobs out they that you don,t even have to go high school to get e.g,software development but need to learn to code.
Ofcourse… Remember success, happiness etc .. these things are determined by factors wayyyyy more complex than some stupid grades…

Get a job. Any job. Work hard, don’t screw around, even if other people do. Learn. Show your boss you’re learning. after two years, if you haven’t been given a raise or been promoted, look for your next job, do the same thing. Then they won’t even worry about your grades, just look at your experience.

Yes they could affect you, if you have grades under 70 ( or worse, 60 ) you need to get help. Do your teachers host tutorials after school or in the morning? I suggest you go to them if you can, well if you have bad marks.

Think about going to a technical college and taking classes that lead to certification and career that does not require a four-year degree.  The first challenge is finding something that you like and commit to learning. Possibilities include:  Surgical technicianLow voltage electrician (people who put in the wiring for computer networks)Auto / diesel mechanic Esthetician

Try brainstorming and making neat notes (e.g. T charts or Cornell notes) of jobs, required skills, salaries, locations, hierarchy rigidity/fluidity, connections, and so on to more easily be a qualified interviewee.

House cleaning, dishwashing, and fast food come to mind. At 18 you might consider that okay. At 36, when many of your friends are employed in air conditioned offices and you are still walking around smelling of Pinesol or kitchen grease, you have to ask yourself if you are going to be equally happy.
learn programming…………………. a dog with programming knowledge can survive in this world…………………………………………………………
